subject: Re: [junit] ExpectedException reset
msgSnippet: Months ago, I was working on a v0.2 of dotmesh that allowed: assrt.thrown(NullPointerException.class).from(this).throwNullPointer();
messageBody:
Months ago, I was working on a v0.2 of dotmesh that allowed:

assrt.thrown(NullPointerException.class).from(this).throwNullPointer();
assrt.thrown(Exception.class).from(this).throwException();

I still hope to get back to it. If the sideways construction would be
worth the added functionality, let me know, and I'll see if I can
bring the project to light faster.

David Saff

On Mon, Sep 27, 2010 at 11:59 PM, Tamas Paulo <Tamas_Paulo@...> wrote:
> Hi David,
>
> Thanks for your answer! Do you know a way, besides try-catch blocks, to expect multiple exceptions in a single test case?
>
> T
>
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of David Saff
> Sent: 2010. szeptember 27. 18:35

> Subject: Re: [junit] ExpectedException reset
>

>
> Tamas,
>
> If you put a System.out.println after your first call to
> throwNullPointer, you'll see that the test ends there. The exception
> ends the test, and then the rule is happy, because it got the
> exception it was looking for. This is the expected behavior.
>
> David Saff
>
> On Mon, Sep 27, 2010 at 7:59 AM, Tamas Paulo <Tamas_Paulo@...<mailto:Tamas_Paulo%40epam.com>> wrote:
>> Hi All,
>>
>> I was using the the ExpectedException rule, and realized that after getting the expected exception it "sinks" every following exception, whats more I couldn't even reset it't expectations.
>> Am I missing something, or is this the proper behavior?
>>
>> See the following code which runs successfully:
>> public class Expect {
>>
>>      @Rule
>>      public ExpectedException exception = ExpectedException.none();
>>
>>      @Test
>>      public void test() throws Exception
>>      {
>>            exception.expect(NullPointerException.class);
>>            throwNullPointer();
>>            throwNullPointer();
>>            throwException();
>>            exception = ExpectedException.none();
>>            throwNullPointer();
>>            throwException();
>>            exception = null;
>>            throwNullPointer();
>>            throwException();
>>      }
>>
>>      private void throwNullPointer()
>>      {
>>            throw new NullPointerException();
>>      }
>>
>>      private void throwException() throws Exception
>>      {
>>            throw new Exception();
>>      }
>> }
>>
>> Thanks in advance,
>> Tamás
>>
